text: Clogged with doughy tourists bulging out of their bathing suits. A long line of cars waiting to park snakes out onto the main road. In the distance, we HEAR the persistent sound of a STUCK CAR HORN getting louder. A BRAND NEW BMW barrels past the line of waiting cars. Steam billows from its severely dented grill. With no regard for anyone, the Beamer swerves in front of an old lady and skids to a stop across the last two handicap spaces. JIM SIMMERS (38) calmly exits the vehicle and begins to peel off his robe and pyjamas one piece at a time as he marches towards a trash can. He’s down to his underwear as he snatches a newspaper out of the PARKING ATTENDANT'S hand and buck naked by the time he squats into the trash can to take a shit. It’s a scene, man. He’s folded in half, ass submerged in the trash can, knees dangling over the side. Jim flips to the sports page, seemingly unaware of the slack-jawed GAWKERS crowded around. The STUCK CAR HORN in the background is accented by a short GRUNT of relief as Jim finishes. He struggles to get out of the can, then pushes past the horrified crowd, bee-lining for the ocean. Naked as a jaybird, he strides purposefully into the cold waters of the Atlantic. The wailing CAR HORN rises in CRESCENDO as we...

head_text.subj: A POT OF BOILING WATER FOR NO GOOD REASON...

text: +.-no good reason whatsoever.

INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - MORNING The barking dog next door wakes Jim up two hours too early, just like always. He’s wearing those same pyjamas, slips on that same robe, walks through his sad little apartment, into...

The proper place to shit. But Jim’s only pissing this morning. Long and pungent. INT. JIM'’S KITCHEN - MORNING Jim sets out his cereal, his juice, his milk and his fiber additives. He adds eight frozen raspberries - not seven, not nine but eight - to his bowl. INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Jim is now dressed in the uniform of middle Management: a short-sleeved dress shirt, maudlin tie, and pleated Dockers®. A backpack slung over both shoulders completes his lame appearance. He picks up a book, “365 Morning Affirmations”, turns to an earmarked page, looks in the mirror...

You're a winner, Jim Simmers. But he’s not. EXT. JIM’S APARTMENT - MORNING Jim peeks out. Looks around. The coast is clear. But the second he steps onto the sidewalk, A BIG ASSHOLE DOG - the same one whose barking woke him earlier - menaces him. Jim stands motionless while the four-legged cocksucker barks maniacally at him. THE GAY NEIGHBOR, a short, shaved-bald fireplug of a dude, steps outside.
A little help here.
I’m so sorry. I don’t know why he’s like that with you. (to the dog) Hoag! David Hoag, you come here! David Hoag trots back to his owner.
I don’t wanna sound like a broken record here, but you kind of promised to keep him locked up. The Gay Neighbor ignores him, fixated on a string dangling from his dog’s ass.
What’d you eat, Hoagster? Huh? (looks waaay up there) You’ve been scavenging, haven’t you Hoagie?
Okay...so...you’1ll leash your dog from now on, right?
(pulling the dog’s legs apart) Huh? Oh, absolutely. Jim shakes his head and proceeds to enter...
Jim straps in and drives off, cranking Duran Duran’s “The Reflex” on his shitbox’s crappy stereo.

Empty. Yet there’s a stoplight. And Jim stops at it despite being the only car out. AN SUV PULLS UP NEXT TO HIM. Jim turns downs his music, self-conscious. Still the light remains red, taunting Jim. The SUV runs it, but Jim waits. And waits. A TRUCK barrels through the light without stopping. Finally it turns green. Jim pulls off.
A Dunkin’ Donuts, a convenience store and a Post Office. Jim’s parks his car politely, climbs out and heads into...
Jim places a newspaper on the counter while a HOT YOUNG CLERK rambles on the phone, ignoring him.

First he fucks the shit out of me, then beats the shit out of me, which would be fine if I wasn’t the one smuggling his crack into prison when I’m visiting his brother. Shit, it’s not like he’s gonna help me get my baby back from the Jamaican assholes we met at the rage... Jim is both intrigued and embarrassed by her conversation.
Can I please-- (she holds up her finger) Can I please-- (finger goes up again) Look, I just need--
(into the phone) Hold on one second, Juno! (to Jim) Here! She punches a few buttons on the lottery machine and shoves the resulting tickets at Jim.
Five quick picks, two megabucks and a daily double, 0-5-0-8, and one Cape Cod Times! Jim pays her and snatches his shit, irked.
You might as well burn your money, man. You’re never gonna win. Jim heads out.
Jim pulls up to a nondescript, multi-story, “God please kill me” office building.

An endless sea of cubicles filled with people doing things and saying things we couldn’t care less about. Jim makes his way to Cubicle 18-C and takes a seat. He opens his top drawer and pulls out a lottery ticket. Checks the numbers against the results in the newspaper... Jim sighs. No luck. As he settles in and puts on his headset, a familiar scent catches his attention. JIM’S P.O.V. as OLIVIA - curvy, gorgeous, wafting sensuality - glides up the stairs to the SECOND TIER. Her ass is fucking perfect. Seriously. Her ass is actually perfect and there’s nothing Jim can do about it.
Six years later and you’re still infatuated... Jim turns...

head_text.subj: IN THE CUBICLE DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO HIS --

text: JILL SUMMERS (early 30’s) - hip, chunky, vibrant, ballsy - sits with her feet on her desk and an unplugged electric guitar in her lap.
You really wanna start? She motions for him to hold on.
(into headset) Yes, ma’am, I understand... She mouths to Jim, “I don’t understand.”
(into headset) Yes, ma’am, I understand. Jill mutes the headset.
Forty three seconds till the coffee rush. Hold my spot if you beat me?
I always beat you. Jill un-mutes the headset.

(into headset) Can you hold while I look up your policy? Thank you. Jill punches the hold button and takes off. Jim is about to follow, but... He’s interrupted by an annoying BUZZING from his desk phone.
(exasperated) Jim, I’ve got a woman on line nine-- she just...she won’t fucking listen to reason. Any chance you can help me out here?
Not a problem.
Thanks, man. I appreciate it. Jim punches a button, unleashing the Kraken.

(into headset) Valid Insurance, Jim Simmers speaking. How may I be of ass-- The woman on the other end immediately launches into a hysterical tirade. Her words are indecipherable, but her rage is unmistakable.
Okay, slow down a minute. Does the letter indicate the reason for the termination of your policy?  Her response is another forty-five second burst of insane chattering.

A bored CO-WORKER stands over the open copy machine hitting the “start” button over and over, seemingly hypnotized by the moving light. Jim approaches with a stack of papers, still dealing with the customer. Jim covers the microphone on his headset.
(to Bored Co-Worker) Uh, you mind? The Bored Co-Worker snaps out of his trance, and steps aside.
(into headset) I agree with you, ma’am. Now if you would just give me your policy number, I can-- Jim runs off copies while the woman runs her mouth.
Two lazy co-workers, SCHOOLEY and McCORKLE, stand around gossiping.

.»+.So I got three fingers in, right? And the chick leans right into my ear and says, “more”, and I’m like, “honey, any more and I’m not gonna be able to drive the van"... His buddy laughs. Their moment of bullshitting is interrupted when Jim approaches. His headset is still buzzing with the irked customer.
(into headset) Ma’am can you hold on a second? (to Schooley and McCorkle) Uh, guys, I’ve gotta get in there. The two slackers shoot him a dismissive look and walk off.
Whatever you say, Captain Overtime. As Jim searches through the files...
Ma’‘am, I really want to help but...
Jim gets in line at the coffee maker. JILL already has her coffee and Jim doesn’t and that’s funny to her. She smirks.
Sucker. He points to his headset, manages a sheepish smile.
(into headset) I understand that it runs in your family, however, your child does weigh in excess of four hundred pounds so-- Jim has to pull the headset away when the woman screeches at him.

Dude, hang up. Life’s too short. But Jim is committed. Plus he’s next in line for coffee, right behind... BLAKE HENDERSON, 29 (but says he’s 27), an overconfident, overachieving dick. The kind of guy who has a big ass coffee cup that says “BIG ASS CUP” on the side. Jim watches in horror as Blake dumps his lukewarm coffee into the sink and pours the last of the fresh coffee into his “big cup.” He shakes the pot to ensure that he’s literally taken every last drop.
(gun-points at Jim and says...) Fuck right, I did. Blake struts off leaving Jim with an empty pot and an angry customer.
(into headset, exasperated) Please, please, please, just tell me what I can do to make this-- CLICK. Jim snatches the fucking headset off his fucking head.
Fuck. He catches Jill smirking from across the room. Jim sighs and starts on a new pot. He sorts through the various brands of shit.
No Starbucks? In the trash lay the last empty bag of Starbucks. Jim holds up seven brands of crap: Maxwell House, Folgers, Munter’s Brown Roast, etc.
Jim Simmers, please report to Mr. Whiteman’s office. He hurriedly selects the bag of Munter’s Brown®, starts the maker on “quick brew”.
Why don’t you just grab a cup up on the second tier?
It doesn’t work like that, Jill. Just because Mr. Whiteman called me to his office doesn’t mean I have second tier privileges.
Dude. The White Man’s not calling you up there to chit-chat, he’s calling you up to promote. And you’re the most promotable guy I know.
I don’t know about the most promotable, but I’ve definitely done the work. The coffee brews oh so slowly. Excruciating. Jim checks his watch...  10.
You’ve got it coming, Jim. Don’t worry. The coffee machine CHIRPS. But now Jim wants to ensure that he has the “right” cup. Each time he picks one up, he puts it back, choosing another.
(intense) I feel like this has to happen, you know? I feel like I’ve done everything that I’m supposed to do and I’ve waited as long as I possibly can...it has to happen today.
Easy, turbo... Finally Jill grabs a cup for Jim and pours.
It’s just a promotion--
It’s a career, Jill. It’s a job now, but it becomes a career by the end of the day. It has to.

Right. Or I’m sure you'll kill everyone here. She punches him playfully in the arm and walks away. Jim steels himself, takes a sip of his coffee... disgusting. Pours it out. INT. MR. WHITEMAN’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Mr. Whiteman sits behind his desk, a serious look etched upon his serious face. Jim enters, ebullient.
(somber ) Jim... It’s all there...in that one word. His face drops.
No.
This wasn’t easy...  11.
No. Blake enters smugly, sipping Starbucks from his Big Ass Cup.
Yeah.
Look, we deliberated for a long time. It was torturous. You guys were both eminently qualified.
Then why? Honestly, why?
Don’t do it to yourself, Jim.
He’s right. Accept it, Jim Simmers, because this is how it is.
No offense to Blake, but I’ve been here longer, my output is higher, I work harder than anyone I know. This doesn’t make any sense. Tell me why?
Jim, what so many people on Earth don’t understand...
...-don’t even fathom...
-..is that so much of life is based on popularity.
Are you kidding?
No. Blake is more popular than you, and I think that counts for something. Silence. Jim gnaws on his lip. Mr. Whiteman notices Jim’s hand clenching.
I need to leave early today.  12.
I think that’s a good idea.
Yeah. I just need you to do one little thing before you leave. INT. JIM’S CUBICLE - DAY Blake plops a big ass stack of files on Jim’s desk. He gives Jim the gun point and walks off.
Jim pulls up and approaches the most perfect house in this perfect neighborhood. We HEAR birds CHIRPING, sprinklers SPRINKLING...and the SOUNDS of a violent struggle inside. Jim knocks.
REBECCA CORDDRY (36), a sweet-faced, dainty buttercup answers.
Jim! Rebecca is the spitting image of a 1950's housewife.
Hey, Becca. Is Rob... Horrible SCREAMS emanate from inside the home.
(re: the sounds) Well, I guess he is home.
Come on in.
A perfect little suburban living room. Jim sits on the couch. Rebecca sits across from him.
He’1l be with you in a minute, he’s just putting Junior down.  13. THE HALLWAY that connects to this living room is alive with the SOUNDS of SOME HORRIBLE FIGHT. Jim looks, sees nothing.
So, how’ve you been?

Eh. It’s all been kind of “eh” lately. Then we see it, at the end of the hallway... ROB CORDDRY, five foot six, 152 pounds of wiry persistence, clamps a choke hold around the neck of his stepson JUNIOR, 14, a massive construct of rage and retardation. The fight SLAMS them out of view.
continue with their small talk.
So...I bet you’re glad to have Rob home.
I am. Whenever he's gone, Junior and I count the days until the off season.
I bet. Not much to talk about.
Junior charges out backwards slamming Rob into a wall until further rewrites.
They struggle for a topic.
So...do you guys have plans for while he’s home?
He’s just back, so we haven't really made any plans. (taps Jim's leg)  14.
I know he can’t wait to go out with the guys though. Jim sighs.
Yep. The guys out on the Cod. From deep within the bowels of this home we hear...
You know what, maybe you oughta go on back and give him a hand. Jim stands. Rebecca hands him a baseball bat.
A local dive with a tropical theme. Rob has bandages over his eye, the pain in his damaged sternum is excruciating as he tries to sit. Rob pounds the bar, tears welling in his eyes.
Oh, motherfuck!
(concerned) He’s really gotten big, Rob.
AHHH! He’s--OH FUCK! Rob is in so much pain he has to smash a glass on the floor.
I’ve gotta stand. I can’t sit, man. (takes a breath) Yeah, the boy’s gotten big. Each time I come home, it’s like he’s grown another three inches.
Uh, doesn’t that kinda...scare you?
No, the doctor said his rage will wain as he gets older.  15.
Really, my main concern is the weight set that Becca bought him. I swear, it’s like he’s training, you know. I mean, he broke my choke-hold three times before I could lock it in.
He’s probably watching those ultimate fights or something.

(all sentimental) I’m away so much, it just kills me. I mean, I’m sure deep down he’s a good kid...and Rebecca’s such a great mom with such a great vagina it’s like, I wish I could put them in a time capsule when I’m away. Then, Rob looks at Jim, suddenly and deeply worried himself.
Do you think he’s training, Jim? Do you think he’s training to kill me? Jim ponders the question: is the retarded boy training to kill his stepfather?
Nah. I mean, you’ve only been his stepdad for what, five years?
Six.

Okay, six. The point is, these things take time. He’1ll come around. nob! LARRY (0.S.) ob! Jim and Rob turn to see LARRY WILLS, 40's, decked out in a tank-top, flip flops and lifeguard shorts. He's a beach parking lot attendant by day and thieving playboy by day, too. Larry is escorted by a MILF who hasn’t yet learned that she’s being taken advantage of.
Welcome home, man.  16. Larry moves in to hug Rob. Rob retreats.
Ahh...the boy’s gotten bigger, huh? (to the MILF) Hon’. She digs up a twenty from her purse.
Babe, Rob’s been gone for four months fishing and shit. Beat. She reluctantly hands him her credit card. Takes a seat.
(eyebrows raised) We've talked about this. She storms off, pissed. Larry focuses on the guys.
I mean, I hate to be rude but, Jesus, bitch... (waves the MILF’s credit card) Drinks on me.
(re: another MILF) Hey, isn’t that that married woman you hooked up with last time I was here? ANOTHER CUTE MILF ACROSS THE BAR stares at Larry.
Hmm, I don’t remember. He waves. She waves. He motions at his cock, ‘you want this?’ She waves. He motions again, ‘you want this?’ She waves. He stands and yells...
You want this?! Huh? His boys shake their heads, ‘good ole Larry.’
(to the guys) I don’t even care, man. I‘11l do it. I’1l do it cuz I’m totally hard. He has a full on, blasting erection tightening his lifeguard shorts.  17.
Christ man, put that away before you get somebody pregnant.

You better watch out, man, or it‘1l be you. (to the irked Waitress standing right there) Six shots and keep ‘em coming. (the Waitress doesn’t move) What? You want some of this? Huh? Now she moves. And now we know Larry Wills.
The guys are loosened up with liquor. The drinks keep coming.
Ten years with this company and I’m still stuck on tier one, with crappy coffee and stupid customers.
Don’t sweat it, man, they’1ll get you the next time.
Easy for you to say, your life is set.
No one’s life is set, Jim.
No, seriously. Rob’s got the family set up, Larry, you've got all those women and the monster cock...I mean what the fuck?
Your problem, Jim, and I don’t wanna make it sound like I’m judging you, but even if you hada cock half the size of mine, you'd probably still want mine cuz it’s so fucking big.
You don’t understand, I’ve done everything right.  18.
I’ve followed every rule, I've worked my ass off, yet I’m almost forty years old with no girlfriend, no money, and a medium-sized cock at best.
You've got more money than me, Bro.
Jim’s co-workers, Blake, Olivia, Jill, and Blah-blah enter. Jill sees Jim and detaches from Blake’s crew.
Jill joins the guys.
Gimme some of that, Jill.
Don’t give me the sweet talk, twelve inch, I know you’re a piece of shit inside. She gives him a peck on the cheek. Breaks out a BOX OF CIGARS with a bow on it.
I got these to celebrate your promotion, but...you know... She hands out cigars.
Yeah, well there’s no point in smoking them now.
You've gotta be kidding. These are Cubans. She waves a cigar under his nose.
Just because you didn’t get the promotion, doesn’t mean these cigars are any less enjoyable.
...or less illegal. Jim hands the cigar back to her.
Might as well give mine to him...  19. He points to Blake, who is sitting across the room with Olivia glomming all over him.
No matter how long you stare at that perfect ass, she’s always gonna be wrong for you.
She’s right. What you need is that. Rob points at a SLIGHTLY DUMPY CHICK across the bar.
No thanks.
Ha! I fucked her. I pushed her stomach right into her forehead. The WAITRESS arrives. Hands Jim a bill.
Blake said this round is on you, something about congratulating him. Jim looks over and Blake gives Jim the gunpoint.
First of all, I don’t congratulate him. Second of all, it’s not even my card.
Damn right, that’s my chick’s money we're spending. Send it back.
Fine, I'll do it. But Blake’s gonna be pissed. As she moves to leave...
Wait. Jim hands her his credit card.
You are such a flounder. Jill pinches the Waitress’s butt, they walk away talking.  20.
I’m not a flounder. It’s the right move, right guys?
Let me ask you this, are you gonna be bitching about it next week?
What am I supposed to do? It’s over, he won.
If you accept it, then it’s over.
So, what? I do what exactly?
You take that bitch by the love handles and fuck the cash out of her. (off their looks) Fuck you guys, it’s a metaphor.
Mongo’s right. He’s fucked up, but he’s right. You gotta march right into that White Man’s office and demand your promotion.
Yeah! You earned that shit, and shit. Jim looks at Blake. Blake has it all. And doesn’t deserve any of it. Jim knocks back his shot.
You know what? You guys are right, you're absolutely right. That promotion is mine! He pounds the bar in emphasis.
Fuck Blake and fuck The White Man. Tomorrow I’m gonna march into that office and take what’s mine! INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - MORNING The dog barks, Jim awakens with kick-ass in his eyes.  21.
Eight motherfucking raspberries.
Jim reads his morning affirmation with extra special sauce.
(into mirror) You can have it all, Jim Simmers. But he can’t. EXT. JIM’S APARTMENT - MORNING The four-legged cocksucker rushes Jim, but Jim beats him to the car. Victory!
(calling out as Jim drives off) Sorry!
Jim waits for the signal while others don’t. For a split-second, he looks around as if he might... Nope.
An insane BLACK HOBO rants. He’s the only black person on Cape Cod. Above him TWO MUNICIPAL WORKERS fuck around with a power line.

This Earth is not fit for man! Only in the afterlife can one find truth and justice. Come all ye faithful, joyful and triumphant, join me! Let go of this Earth and join me... The Black Hobo pulls out a toy pistol and puts it to his head. He sees Jim pull up in his Sporty Kia Spectrum (with racing stripe). Jim gets out and heads toward the store.  22.
You! Dolemite! Join me! Jim speeds up but the bum rushes him.
Join me and I will complete your training. With our combined strength we can end this destructive conflict and bring order to the galaxy. (suddenly lucid) I know why you’re unhappy. Jim stops.

This is not your Earth. You can never find justice here amongst the wicked, but fear not. The afterlife awaits you. True heaven. True joy. Jim stares at the magical Negro and senses truth in his words. This is what he’s been waiting to hear.
The big payoff is coming.
The Municipal Workers rear back, trying to avoid a severed, flailing power line. But Jim is too riveted by the Hobo to notice the wire. Or the puddle of water he’s standing in.
(with zealotous zeal) The big payoff is coming and-- (suddenly terrified)
The Bum jumps back as the wire makes contact with the water and fries Jim alive.
Jim stands in space. Nothing above him, nothing around him.  23.
Where am I? (realizes) Oh, my God. The black bum was right. Jim smiles in a way we’ve not seen before. True joy.
Come. Come take me... Jim falls to his knees, arms beckoning upward like Shawshank Redemption. Long beat.
I’m ready, um, Lord, or whoever. Hook me up. Jim looks out, still Shawshanked...absolutely nothing.
Come!
A magnificent tunnel of light opens up, beckoning... But Jim is still looking forward, clueless as always. He stands.
Really? The light behind him grows even more magnificent’er. If only he’d just turn around...
No? (then) I don’t even get this? Seriously! No pearly gates? I’ve waited for so Goddamn long...I mean, I’m not damning you, but come on! EVERYTHING SUDDENLY GOES BLACK.
Jim explodes into consciousness. The Black Hobo is pounding on his chest.  24.
Don’t you die on me, man. You’ve never backed away from a fight in your life! Jim tries to push the Bum off. A COP CAR PULLS UP. The Black Hobo punctuates each word with a head slap.
Say you, say me! SAY YOU, SAY ME! The COPS rush the bum. They snatch him away. Jim stands up. Groggy. The bum breaks free and does a flying kick into Jim’s chest.
Don’t die on me! The Cops pin the bum down. Handcuff him. One of the COPS steps to Jim.
Are you okay, sir? Jim looks down. His feet are smoldering. His mind reeling.

No. (looks up to heaven) I’m really, really disappointed. INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - TIME LAPSE Jim lays on the couch submerged in a bout of existential depression. OUTSIDE HIS WINDOW the sun goes up and down as the world turns. Days pass, Jim doesn’t move, half asleep, half awake. Finally, he sits up.
Jim picks up the remote with a sigh. Turns on the TV. THE TELEVISION is suddenly alive with Tom Cruise.
(from “Mission: Impossible”) Jim? The image JUMPS forward to an anguished close-up.  25.
Why, Jim? Why? That’s weird. Jim switches the channel. Low and behold... THE TELEVISION offers more Tom Cruise on this channel.
(from “Jerry Maguire”) Help me. Help me help you. Help me help you! Jim switches the channel. And again...
(from “All The Right Moves”) Doesn’t this seem just a little bit too crazy?
Yes. Yes, it does. Jim changes the channel. THE TELEVISION won’t stop. It’s like Tom Cruise is speaking directly to Jim.
(from “The Color of Money”) It’s like a nightmare, isn’t it?
This is nuts.
Man, it just keeps getting worse and worse, doesn’t it? Jim hits the remote. And there he is again, in tight close-up.
(from “Days of Thunder”) When I’m driving, I got a guy on the radio who talks to me. I can’t see him but he talks to me.
So what’s your point? The image FREEZES. Jim changes the channel.  26.
(from “Cocktail”) What does it mean? NOTHING!
That much I figured out on my own. Click.

(from “Magnolia” ) In this big game that we play - LIFE - it’s not what you hope for, it’s not what you deserve...it’s what you TAKE! The image FREEZES. Jim stares for a long moment, trying to process the universe’s code. He hits the remote one last time...

(from “Risky Business”) Sometimes you just gotta say what the fuck. Make your move. The television’s holy glow takes us to... INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - NEXT MORNING SUNLIGHT. The barking dog wakes Jim. He gets up.

He pulls out his penis with his hand and steadies it to shoot pee out of the tip. It’s a magnificent stream, powerful after days of build up. When droplets hit the seat, Jim ignores them and moves on.

Jim pulls out his cereal, his juice, his raspberries and his fiber additives. He looks at his boring breakfast, turns to the freezer and grabs a vat of ice cream... Jim spoons it from the carton as he walks out.  27. INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - MORNING He stands before the mirror, shoveling ice cream into his maw at an alarming rate. He stares at his reflection for a long moment.

What’s the point? Jim tosses the half empty carton of ice cream over his shoulder and moves on. EXT. JIM’S HOUSE - MORNING Jim exits the house lethargically, dragging his backpack behind him. Within seconds, that asshole dog is upon Jim, snarling and barking like the asshole he is. Jim doesn't slow, doesn’t acknowledge the dog in any way. Just proceeds to his sporty KIA (with racing stripe) and climbs in.
Come back here, Hoagster! Bad Hoagie! That’s a bad Hoagie. The dog continues to snap and snarl as Jim cranks “THE REFLEX” and pulls away.

Same scene, different day. Jim’s sporty KIA slows to a stop. “THE REFLEX” continues to blare even as a carload of judgemental TEENS pulls up beside him. They laugh at Jim. They laugh at his gay music. Some even point at him while they do it. Teens can be so cruel. So cruel. But it doesn’t affect Jim in the least. And he’s done waiting at this stupid light. He steps on the accelerator and zooms away.

The Cute Clerk babbles away on the phone as Jim makes his way to the magazine rack. Grabs himself a copy of LOOSE & JUICY magazine and proceeds to the counter.  28. The clerk sees Jim, punches some buttons on the Lotto machine. Jim shakes his head, ‘no.’ Opens the magazine to the centerfold and holds it up. The clerk is horrified. Jim tosses some bills on the counter and leaves.

Workers gather around as Blake shows off the brand new BMW M-3 that he bought with his promotion bonus. Olivia is particularly impressed. As Jim walks by, disgusted, Blake winks and shoots him the gunpoint.
Jim chucks his backpack into his cubicle as he heads for the kitchen.
He pauses when he sees people crowded around the broken coffee machine. Drops his head exasperated, then... Looks up to the empty coffee room on the second tier. Decides.
As Jim ascends the stairs, his CO-WORKERS gawk.
(fearful) What’s he doing? / He’s crazy! Jill rushes over to stop him but freezes at the first step. She doesn’t dare set foot on it.
(looking up at Jim) Jim, come back! You can’t go up there! But Jim keeps going.  29.

Olivia stands alone, shocked to see... Jim walking right toward her. He takes the creamer out of her hand, then grabs the entire pot of coffee and walks out. Olivia squints, piqued by Jim’s robust flavor.
Jim pours a cup, adds his cream, and leaves the gourmet coffee for the rest of his co-workers. They gather around the pot, sniffing it like wine.
Smell the aroma. Jill pours a small sip. Swirls it around in her mouff.
Oh, my God...no clumps.
And it doesn’t taste like mud. INT. JIM’S CUBICLE - MORNING Jim has his headset on, leaned all the way back in his chair, talking to a customer...

(into headset; flat, emotionless) I’m trying to help you, ma’am but you’ve got to answer the question, okay? How fat are your kids? While the person on the line yells Jim twirls his chair, waiting for his turn to speak. He notices Jill in her cubicle, talking to a customer on the phone as she applies the final touches to a pencil sketch.
(into phone) Yes, sir, I’m checking for you right now. She holds it up for Jim to see.  30.
revealing a realistic rendering of Jim joyfully feeding Blake into a meat grinder.
spins away in his chair, offering no reaction.
..-Ma’am...okay, sorry, sir. Sir, I understand, but “husky” isn’t a medical diagnosis. Jill sighs, breaks out her eraser and changes the smile on drawn Jim’s face to a frown.

I need a number... What do I mean? Like combined do your twins weigh more than your car?...Offended? Sorry. Please, just give me a number... (almost falls out of his chair when he hears the number) You're fucking kidding me. How much? (awed Are they like, seven feet tall? No? (punches his keyboard) Well, I’m looking at the actuarial table now and unless your twins are LeBron James and Shaquille O'Neal, they ain’t gonna qualify. (interrupts the customer’s rant) Hold on--hold on--hold on, I just gotta ask this. I mean, there’s no way on earth any reputable firm is gonna insure those orcas of yours, but I feel the need to ask to satisfy my own curiosity. Why’d you ever marry a fat chick? Click. Jim takes off the headset. Leans forward, despondent. His phone rings incessantly.
(behind him) Hard day, huh? Jim looks up. Blake drops a load of files on his desk.  31.
Make these a priority.

as he struts through the office, finger pointing and being obnoxious. He slaps Jill’s ass then takes a donut out of CO-WORKER 2: THE SPAWNING’S petite hand. After one bite, Blake tosses the donut and heads upstairs. BLAKE’S OFFICE - SECOND TIER - CONTINUOUS Blake enters and is shocked to see... Jim standing there with the files.
Um... Jim holds out the files and drop kicks them...papers fly all over the room. Jim gives Blake the gunpoint...
Fuck yeah I did. ...and walks out.
Beautiful. Right on the water. The sound of heterosexual sex emanates from inside.

Everything about this place says “old money”, including the old money lady, MAUREEN, being pounded from behind by Larry. Larry’s face is curled in disgust, tears streaming down his cheeks. And yes, he does indeed have a clothespin on his nose.
(near climax) Oh, yes! Oh YESSS!!! Fucky me Lenny! Fucky me like you need a job!  32. Larry punches a pillow in olfactory agony. Without warning, A MAN appears in the doorway.
Shit! Larry pulls out, grabs the lamp from the night stand defensively. Maureen stays right where she is.
Jim? Is that you? Yep. It’s Jim.
I need to talk to you, Larry. Now. Larry is torn. Money on the bed, friend in crisis.
Seriously, I need to talk.
That’s it. Mood ruined. She grabs a robe and heads to the bathroom.
While Jim talks, Larry steals. He rifles through drawers and jackets.
I think I’m having a meltdown, Larry.
Watch for Maureen.
I died--I saw the other side and there’s nothing. Larry holds up a diamond watch.
(re: the watch) Too personal? Yeah. (sets it back down) Is the shower still running?

Are you paying attention, man?  33. Larry notices a big ass change jar and starts stuffing his pockets. He freezes when Maureen enters, wearing only a towel. An awkward beat. Errant coins slip from his fists.
Um, Jim, can we deal with your meltdown later?
Are you joking? All the times I’ve picked you up when you were drunk, or bailed you out of jail? You can’t listen to me for five goddamn minutes?
(whispers) I’m kinda working here, Jim. Jim throws Larry against the wall and digs through his pockets. Pulls out a pirate’s booty.
You’re not working. Why don’t you just tell her instead of stealing! Man-up and sell your cock with some respect. Maureen isn’t even slightly phased.

What? You think his stealing is news to me? I leave this crap out on purpose. (slaps Larry’s ass) Go ahead. I’11 take a rain check. Larry nonchalantly pockets the watch. Jim just shakes his head. INT. JIM’S CAR - LATER Jim drives aggressively. Larry leans over to check the speedometer.
Did you really die and shit? Jim grabs one of his melted shoes from the back seat, drops it into Larry’s lap.
What do you think?  34. Larry stares at the shoe.
These cost like ninety--
That’s not the point!
Oh.
The point is: there is no point. There’s nothing, man. Some people have it all, and some people have shit. He pulls up to Rob’s house.
I have shit. INT. ROB’S GARAGE - DAY Rob is in his garage cleaning dried blood off of his hooks and spiked clubs. Larry and Jim enter.
Whoa! That’s sick!

(proud) Yeah, I designed it for the new guys on the job. Nothing worse than seeing some noob half-spiking his club in a wounded harp seal’s head without making the kill shot. It’s almost cruel. Larry notices an instructional poster on the wall detailing the proper way to kill baby seals.
I don’t know how you do it, Rob. How can you look into that cute little face and smash it. How do you smash their adorable little faces off?
Hey, I’ve gotta support my family. And you know what, it’s racist against cows to care about harp seals.  35.
(vexed by that fucked up sentence)

head_text.subj: WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU TALKING

text: Cows are thinking creatures too, but no one minds killing them. Why are harp seals so special? (off the guys’ faces) Cows make great pets and they’re very protective unlike harp seals that have a horrible side no one ever sees.
(dead serious) Come on, Rob. Don’t try to justify your murder by player hating on harp seals. They don’t hurt anyone and shit, you do!

You're out of your element, short bus! You wouldn’t believe what I’ve seen those creatures do. I’ve seen that white fur covered in blood...and not always their own. Before it can turn into an argument, Jim jumps in.
Enough! Silence.

No more fighting about baby harp seals. You guys don’t seem to understand, there’s no God, there’s no heaven, there’s nothing! All we get is this! And for me, this-- this whole thing--everything...it’s been a waste!
What’s going on?
He died and now he’s getting all--
What do you mean he died.  36.
I was electrocuted. I saw the other side and there. Was. Nothing!
Um...
Look, these rules that we live by, they’re meaningless. Why not grab a woman by her tit and tell her you want to fuck her?
I do it all the--
Shut up, Larry. Why have any restraint at all? Why not do whatever you fucking want, whenever the fuck you want, cuz ultimately it doesn’t matter at all...THERE’S

head_text.subj: NO FUCKING PAYOFF...TO ANY OF IT

text: MONSTROUS GROANS rumble from inside the house. Rob instinctively tightens his grip on the club. Beat.
(staring at the walls) You're scaring Junior. (then) You need to calm down...
(calmly) No. Fuck no. I don’t need to calm down. I have spent my entire life “calming down.” From here on out, I’m getting what I want.
Um, what is it? What do you want? Jim grabs a sharpie and writes on the wall... 1. . That jes.” 2. "That car” 3. “That chick”  37.

(as he writes) I want that promotion. I want that Beamer that Blake bought with that promotion. And you know what? I wanna fuck Olivia. I wanna fuck her in the ass. The guys are quiet, mesmerized by Jim’s new outlook. Just then, Rebecca enters with a plate of fresh baked cookies...and two black eyes.
(sing-songy) Who wants cookiiieees? Larry reaches for one, burns his hand...too hot.
And I want those. Jim grabs a handful of cookies.
Melty chocolate that would normally be delicious scalds Jim’s hands. But he pounds them down, disintegrating his mouth with abandon.
Oh, god!
Dude, wait till they cool--
Fuck that...ARRG! Jim eats damn near every one, his face clenched in agony.
Maybe you could leave this last one for somebody else. Jim snatches the last cookie off the plate and belligerently smashes it all over his face before he eats it.
The office is dark, shut down, except for one room.  38.
Jim holds a list, picking through the infinite rows of files. He drops the ones that match into a basket. Jill enters.
This better be good, you calling me in here at midnight. He hands her the basket.
(terse) Verify that all contact information in these files is current.
Excuse me. Do I work for you?
Didn’t mean to be curt, I’m just really focused right now. She flips through the files.
These are all Blake’s clients.
Yep.
What are you up to, Turbo?

Taking back what’s mine. EXT. MR. WHITEMAN’S HOUSE - BACKYARD - DAY A barbecue for all the people who matter is in full swing. Brie cheese, fine champagne, and stiff upper lips abound. Schooley and McCorkle are off to the side, doing what they do...
.--holy shit, your fist must have smelled like ham salad.  39.

Still does. I’ve been soaking my hand in tomato juice for two weeks and it still reeks like spoiled cock-garbage. McCorkle holds out his hand. Schooly leans in, takes a long whiff and instantly recoils from the stench.
Holy Jesus! That smells just like my dream. Meanwhile, at the center of the party, Blake has a crowd of rich folk entranced.
.-.-and I’ve got a little poem that I’d like to read in honor of this occasion, if I may. He unfolds a slip of paper and begins to read.

“It’s easy to grin, when your ship comes in, and you’ve got the stock market beat. But the man worthwhile, is the man who can smile, when his shorts are too tight in the seat.” The crowd laughs haughtily. Blake’s unearned popularity is mind-numbing. Olivia stands off to the side, stunning and bored. Mr. Whiteman’s WIFE pats Blake’s head like a good dog.
So entertaining...and popular too. I’ve always thought you’d fit in nicely. Blake’s moment in the sun is dashed when...

head_text.subj: TRACY, A FOUR-FOOT TALL, 300-POUND ADOLESCENT, ENTERS

text: LIKE A TASMANIAN DEVIL, screaming and stealing food from everyone and slamming it into her face.
(between bites) BANNH! Spicy bean burgers...BORPH!  40.
Jim and Rob escort a number of other obese, crippled, and differently-abled people into the backyard. Mr. Whiteman approaches, outraged.
What the hell are you doing? Who are these people...what are these people? In the background, Tracy chases down a woman with a plate of ribs.
BAAARRG! Jimme more meat sauce!
Olivia and Mrs. Mr. Whiteman watching from afar.
What in blazes is wrong with that horrible child?
(bored) If I had to guess, I’d say Prader- Willi syndrome.
flattens the woman with a backside clothesline. OLIVIA NODS.
Yep, that’s Prader-Willi, alright.
What is that?
It’s a rare genetic disorder that causes compulsive eating and irrational behavior. TRACY eats the ribs off the ground, screaming to the sky like a victorious predator.

head_text.subj: BACK TO JIM AND MR. WHITEMAN

text: Explain, Jim. Now!

These are your policy holders. I thought you should meet the people your company has been paying millions of dollars in claims to. Jim grabs BLINDY, a fifty-year-old wheezing blind man with an oxygen mask over his face.
This is Blindy, he--
(rasping) Trevor. My name is--

This is Blindy Trevor. He's... (reads Blindy’s file) Twenty-three-years-old with absolutely no history of health problems. Yet as you can see, he’s at least fifty, blind as a bat and suffering from advanced emphysema. Mr. Whiteman squints. Outrage gives way to “tell me more.”
as he exits the house, zipping up. He spots Jim with Whiteman...this can’t be good.
Hey! Blake rushes over. Wedges himself between Jim and Mr. Whiteman.
How dare you, Jim Simmers. This is a private function on private property and you are specifically not invited. Now pack up these mongoloids and get--

Quiet, Blake. Don’t say another word. (to Jim) Continue...  42. Jim points to a woman (FRANCESCA) in an overturned wheelchair. She feebly attempts to fight off... TRACY, who violently yanks at a candy bar that has somehow gotten tangled in Francesca’s hair.
And that is Francesca. Look at her...
Mounds! Mounds! JIMME MOUNDS! Tracy can’t get the candy bar out of Francesca’s hair, so she starts gnawing on the crippled woman’s bouffant.
Get it off me! Get it off me!
(to Jim) Jim?
Not yet. (hands Mr. Whiteman a file) On paper, Francesca is twenty four years old, never been sick a day in here life, and makes her living as a lifeguard.
Oh GOD! It HURTS!
But as you can see, she can’t swim. She can’t possibly swim. Tracy drags Francesca by her hair. Francesca flails, trying to cling to her wheelchair.
Get to the point, Simmers.
The point is that you have been defrauded, Mr. Whiteman. By one of your own employees. Stunned faces all around.

head_text.subj: BACK TO OLIVIA AND MRS. MR. WHITEMAN

text: as they survey Tracy’s path of destruction.
My god. How do we stop her?
You can’t. She can’t help herself. Mrs. Mr. Whiteman sighs, shakes her head as she regards the collection of misfits on her lawn.

Goddamn circus people. Olivia shoots her a chastising look and moves toward the action. STAY WITH Mrs. Mr. Whiteman as she plucks the olives from her martini glass and pops them into her mouth. Just as she’s beginning to chew... WHHHUMMP! Tracy knocks her to the ground.

Tracy, her face a deep brown smear of chocolate and hair, grabs Mrs. Mr. Whiteman by the ears and tries to forcibly suck the pre-chewed olives from her mouth. Mrs. Mr. Whiteman manages a MUFFLED, HIGH-PITCHED SCREAM... +..one that only Mr. Whiteman can hear. He cocks his head like a dog, then turns to see his wife under retarded assault.
(panicked, to Jim) For the love of god, call off that creature! Rob remains standing with his hands behind his back.
Rob? Rob unclenches his hands, revealing a baseball bat tight in his grip.
(with a gleam in his eye) I’m on it. Whiteman watches Rob move to save his wife. He turns back to Jim.
Who has dared defraud me? OFFSCREEN, we HEAR a series of horrible “THWACKS”, punctuated with pained cries from Tracy.
Now is not the time for this discussion, sir. I mean, your wife is being mauled by a four hundred pound goonie bird. Perhaps we should--
Didn’t I tell you not to speak? (to Jim) I want names.
(indicating the retard army) Why don’t you ask them...
Well speak up. Who sold you your policies? One by one, they all say the same thing... “Blake Henderson.” Mr. Whiteman is aghast.
(to Blake) Henderson is this true?
No--well, yes, but not really. Kind of. It’s very complicated... Jim hands his stack of files to Mr. Whiteman.
It’s all right there. The White Man levels his cold blue eyes on Blake.
Blake, you’re fired.
But I--I’m the most--what about my popularity?  45.
Get out. Blake looks at Jim, gives him the gunpoint.
I...I never thought you had it in you. Blake skulks off. Whiteman clasps Jim on the shoulder.

I guess you’re my man now, Jim Simmers. Congratulations. He walks Jim into the heart of the barbecue. The crowd embraces him. Olivia moves to his side. Jim takes the glass of champagne from her hand and gulps it down...just like he’s gonna do her in a few days. WE PULL BACK, past a table where...

head_text.subj: ROB HAS TRACY PINNED FACE DOWN --

Shhh. Shhhhhhhh.

in SLOW MOTION as Jim enters the office like a rock star. Jim nods to his former co-workers who gaze upon him in awe. High fives are slapped. Jim gives the “you know it” nod to all those who are now beneath him.
Pauses. Looks back at the adoring crowd. A single tear in his eye. As Jim takes that first monumental step towards true happiness, the crowd erupts in applause.  46.

(sotto; heartfelt) Today, I win. I win it hard. Jim climbs to the top of the stairs. He absolutely MUST give them one last parting glance. EVEN SLOWER MOTION as Jim looks down, not at his fans but at his defiant erection. His hard, hard defiant erection. He sticks it out for the crowd below, just a little bit...but enough. Goddamn he has gusto.

SUPER: “45 Minutes Later...” INT. JIM’S NEW OFFICE - DAY A palatial high tech office dominated by a huge oak desk, a big screen TV and a wet bar. Jim is slumped in his chair, miserable. The phone is ringing, the files before him sit unaddressed. He doesn’t even have his kick ass boner anymore. Without warning, Rob and Larry barge in followed closely by JIM’S NEW SECRETARY.
Look at these digs. This place is fucking opulent and shit.
I’m sorry sir...these men DO NOT have an appointment and I....
(to Secretary) They’re fine, Cindy. Leave us.
Yes, Mr. Simmers. She leaves. Rob prowls the office like a kid ina candy store.
This office is incredible, man.  47.
(without enthusiasm) Yeah. Rob crosses to the big screen.
Holy shit! Is that a fifty-inch?
Sixty. Larry spies the Johnnie Walker Blue label at the wet bar.
Johnnie Walker Blue? GODDAMN, that shit is almost as good as Johnnie Walker Green! Can I have some?
The Blue is better than the Green.
No it’s not. Can I have some?
Yes it is. Right, Jim?
Look fool, everyone knows the Green is the best. Cuz it costs more. Can I have some, Jim?
How do you figure?
What color is money, man? Ipso facto, motherfucker... Rob just shakes his head.
Can I have some...?
Take it.
Take the Blue? Like all of it?
Take the whole bottle. I don’t care.  48.
What’s wrong with you, man? I mean, you’ve got the sweet office, the Johnnie Walker blue...you’re living the life now, man.
I dunno. It seems like it should be...better.
The bar is empty except for our guys. Jim has a mean buzz going.
Man, I don’t know any other job that let’s you get drunk in the middle of the day. A WAITER steps up. Drops off a few beers.
(to the waiter) Hey, what’s the most expensive drink in this place?
This is a dive bar, dude.
Come on, what’s the most expensive drink you’ve ever served? The Waiter thinks for a moment.
Well, some rapper from New York was once in here, throwing his black rap money around. He ordered...what was that...oh yeah, he ordered a Long Island Iced Tea made with all top shelf liquor.
Perfect. We'll take six.
I’m gonna need a deposit on that.
. (tipsy) NO! No. Jim, no.
It’s okay, Larry. Jim pulls out a credit card. As he’s handing it to the waiter, Larry snatches it. Inspects it.
Holy shit...company credit. That shit’s gangsta. The Waiter grabs the card from Larry and heads to the bar. Jim drops his head, frustrated with everything.
Bargh.
Bargh? Why bargh? You’re in the game now. You’re checking off the list, man. In a year or so you’ll be able to afford that car, and--
A year? Fuck a year. I got enough in my savings to buy that car now. Outright.
Out-motherfucking-RIGHT!
You can’t spend your savings on a car, Jim.
Why? Why can’t I do it?
Because it’s just not done. Savings are--they’re for...later.
I personally have conclusive fucking proof that there is no later. Sometimes, you just gotta say I don’t give a fuck--
--and steal a bitch’s money.
(nodding) Sometimes you’ve got to go large or stay at home.  50. Rob has no idea what he’s talking about. But Larry does. He and Jim bump knuckles.
Players do what they want to, suckers do what they can.

FUCKIN’ A RIGHT! That! That right there... (points into Larry’s mouth) That’s what I’m talking about. The Waiter arrives with their drinks in tall, precious glasses. Jim grabs his, downs it, wipes his mouth.
Let’s do this!

A fleet of shiny Beamers and our three guys. Rob is cradling four sloshing Long Island Iced teas in his arms, staining everything in his vicinity. Larry holds a small BRIEFCASE while trying to eat a scalding pizza, too drunk to understand that it needs to cool. Jim has an even meaner buzz going. When the CAR SALESMAN comes over, Jim glares at him.
(thick country accent) Hey, ya'll. Looking to buy or just lookin’? The Salesman looks behind him, unable to comprehend why Jim is glaring so viciously. Rob hands Jima drink.
(points at a car) I want that silver M-3, right there. How much?
Oh, that’s a beaut’. It’s fully loaded, ya’ll. I reckon.  51.
Look, no pitch, this is gonna be the easiest sale you’1l ever make. How much?
Well, now, lemme just tell you’n what this here lil’o jewel gots under the hood. The Salesman is getting progressively more country with each exchange.
I’ve got cash. How much?
Yeah, how much?
Well, as I’m sure you’n alls knows, the Beamer M W is not for the common, man. But, now, I wouldn’t reckon you is--
How. Much?
Well, that’d all depend. You see, this one here, that you’se is gazing upon, this one’s the Tiger Edition. It’s got double aluminum crank shafts and--
I don’t care. How much?
I’m sure you wanna know what you’re gettin’. And what you’d be gettin’. While the Salesman talks, Jim grabs the briefcase and cracks it open. It’s full of cash.

...-I mean, one might mosey on down to the hoosegow with a big ole posse’a desperados and commence to demanding all kinds’a things, I reckon. But don’t mess with Texas, that’s where I’d be hailin’ outta, ya know--  Silence. that he price. 52.
Why won’t you answer?
Sir, I see you're serious--
NO! That’s not an answer. A proper answer is a number. A number that will allow me to hand you this cash and drive off with that car.
But, now don’t get yer dander up, cowboy. I’m gonna lay down the statistics--
Motherfucker! How much is the car? You’re in the business of selling cars! Just give me a price. The Salesman seems to finally have grasped needs to shut the fuck up and give Jima
Hey now, I’m here to work with you. We got different financing options that a fella such as yerself may want to choose from.

Different from a briefcase full of cash? The Salesman’s mouth moves, but he can’t form a sentence that is a direct answer. Rob rolls his eyes, grabs a slice of pizza, peels off the cheese and slams it sauce-first into the Salesman’s face. The molten sauce scalds him and sets him screaming.
PRAAAAAHHHHHHH-YA‘LL!!! Rob kneels beside the writhing Salesman and begins peeling off another piece of pizza.
(whispers ) How much?  53.
The guys are packed in, riding in style. Jim fiddles with the stereo as he drinks and drives.
(to Rob) What the hell got into you back there?
Yeah, you went all Vietnam or some shit, like that salesman was a freakin’ harp seal or something! Rob squints, trying to process what he just did.
The dude was wasting our time.
Yeah but it cost me an extra two grand to keep him from pressing charges.
Like you say, sometimes you just gotta say, who the fuck cares, right?
I don’t. I don’t care about shit!
Button it, Rainman. You’d have to understand to care. Jim swerves, irked that his radio sucks...
This stupid car doesn’t have satellite! (looking back) How can this be the ultimate driving machine and not have satellite? All of a sudden, Jim comes up on tail lights. He hits the brakes.

What the--  54. EXT. MID-CAPE HIGHWAY - “SUICIDE ALLEY” - NIGHT A TWO LANE STRETCH OF HIGHWAY with flexible plastic pylons going down the center. Jim’s new beamer is being cock-blocked by a FAMILY OF TOURISTS driving half the speed limit. Nothing but open road in front of them. INT. JIM’S BMW - CONTINUOUS Jim rides the tourists’ bumper.
Oh, my God! He hits the horn.
I don’t get it. The speed limit is 65, why is this douchebag driving 40 miles an hour?
You know, the speed “limit” isn’t the speed “requirement.” It’s the limit. It’s the fastest you’re allowed to go. So really, this guy is just choosing not to ride at maximum capacity.
Yeah, but there are also speed minimums. It’s as unsafe to drive slow on a highway as it is to drive fast.
No. No, Rob. No. Slow is always safer.
You’re a retard, just like my boy...but without the strength.
Did you just call your stepkid a retard? Robert gulps the last drop of the last Long Island.
Fuck yeah I did. Cuz he is.  55.
Whoa.
Look, there’s no harm in calling a spade a spade as long as you appreciate the spade.
(serious as a heart attack) You’re a goddamn racist, man. And it sickens me. Jim has had enough. He pulls into the center of the road to pass - the pylons strike his Beamer - THWACK!
An oncoming car forces him back into his lane.
Hey, be careful man. Those pylons--
I know what I’m doing. No stupid plastic pylons gonna hurt The Ultimate Driving Machine®.
Yeah, but some of them...
I do whatever I want. All the time.
Yeah, but... Jim lays on the horn, pulls back into the center of the road. THWACK!! THWACK! THWACK!
The Beamer strikes a SOLID pylon, mangling the grill. The car horn WAILS, stuck. Steam wafts into the atmosphere. As the car limps to the breakdown lane...
Some of them are filled with concrete. A beat.  56. Until Rob bursts out in a fit of uncontrollable laughter.
HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH you fucking asshole HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! Whatever. Jim jams the car into gear. He stabs at the radio switching stations.
Goddamn analog radio. Goddamn everything. Goddamn every fucking molecule in the goddamn world.

From off in the distance we hear it. We hear it coming... The horn. Jim’s new newly fucked up Beamer pulls in front of the house, horn blaring. The back door opens. Before Larry can set both feet on the sidewalk, Jim tears off. Larry shakes his head. Sighs. Digs a clothespin from his pocket, clamps it on his nose, and walks to the front door. EXT. ROB’S HOUSE - NIGHT We see the silhouette of Rob’s massive son, standing on the roof, screaming at the moon. Not howling, screaming...
Moon! Mooocoocooon!!! His screams meld with the sound of... Jim’s car horn. The beamer pulls up. Rob gets out. Jim tears off and leaves his friend to face his son. Alone.

Junior turns away from the moon and locks eyes with Rob. He squints, ‘oh, yeah, it’s on.’  57. Rebecca comes out with a roll of tape. Rob holds out his hands so she can tape his knuckles. INT. JIM’S HOUSE - NIGHT Jim enters. Tosses his keys. Heads straight for the bedroom. INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sleep eludes him as Jim stares at the ceiling, contemplating his fate.
INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - MORNING The neighbor’s dog is barking. Jim’s eyes snap open. He sits up with purpose.
It’s a disaster area. Jim enters and paints another yellow layer. He pees indiscriminately, all over the floor, the toilet, the walls...whatever. He exits without flushing.

Jim strolls in wearing sweats and a wife beater. He grabs a stick of butter from the fridge. Takes a box of Strawberry Nestle’s® Quick from the cabinet. He jams the butter in the Quick and takes a bite. And that shit is good. While he eats his strawberry butter, Jim collects various wash rags from his kitchen.
Jim is now wearing a T-shirt over the wife beater, and he’s holding a pile of other shirts and pants. He puts them on, layer after layer. Then he starts wrapping his hands with the rags.  58.
Jim bangs on the door, wrapped in cotton armor. The Gay Neighbor answers.
Morning, Jim. What’s with the--

Who? Jim pushes past him.
Jim freezes when he sees...

head_text.subj: AN ENTIRE WALL COVERED FLOOR TO CEILING WITH FRAMED

text: PHOTOS OF THE GAY NEIGHBOR’S DOG... FUCKING. Dozens of pictures of Hoag mounting other dogs. Hundreds of them really. Poodles and Schnauzers, Shih-Tzus and Beagles, all getting pounded from behind. Tiny Dachshunds and Chihuahuas are barely visible beneath Hoag’s massive chest. The Shepherds and Labradors look sad. (self-conscious) Please don’t think I’m weird. It’s a long story. Jim stares at him. Long silence.

I’m out of my mind...you know that, right? Jim shakes it off and marches past him.  59. EXT. THE GAY NEIGHBOR’S BACKYARD - CONTINUOUS 160 pounds of four-legged, cocksucking, Bull Mastiff yanks against his spiked chain, crazed, frothing. This is a very serious dog. Jim takes a deep breath.
(without looking back) Let him off. The Gay Neighbor moves from behind Jim, and approaches his dog. He seems a bit frightened by his own beast.
Jim, I can’t let him off. Look at him.
This has to happen.
